Sentence: ARTHUR: No, no, no, no, i--
ARTHUR: No, it's not that. It's 'ni'.
ROGER THE SHRUBBER: Are you saying 'ni' to that old woman?
ROGER: Oh, what sad times are these when passing ruffians can say 'ni' at will to old ladies.
There is a pestilence upon this land.
Even those who arrange and design shrubberies are under considerable economic stress at this period in history.
I arrange, design, and sell shrubberies.
SCENE 18: Shrubbery or Herring? That is the Question
ARTHUR: O Knights of Ni, we have brought you your shrubbery.
HEAD KNIGHT: It is a good shrubbery.
I like the laurels particularly,... but there is one small problem.
HEAD KNIGHT: We are now... no longer the Knights Who Say 'Ni'.
We are now the Knights Who Say 'Ecky-ecky-ecky-ecky-pikang-zoop-boing-goodem-zu-owly-zhiv'.
HEAD KNIGHT: Therefore, we must give you a test.
ARTHUR: What is this test, O Knights of-- knights who till recently said 'ni'?
HEAD KNIGHT: Firstly, you must find... another shrubbery! [dramatic chord]
HEAD KNIGHT: Then, when you have found the shrubbery, you must place it here beside this shrubbery, only slightly higher so you get the two-level effect with a little path running down the middle.
HEAD KNIGHT: Then, when you have found the shrubbery, you must cut down the mightiest tree in the forest... with... a herring! [dramatic chord]
ARTHUR: We shall do no such thing!
ARTHUR: Cut down a tree with a herring?
Suffice to say is one of the words the Knights of Ni cannot hear.
ARTHUR: How can we not say the word if you don't tell us what it is?
HEAD KNIGHT: You said it again!
You wouldn't get vary far in life not saying 'is'.
BEDEVERE: My liege, it's Sir Robin!
MINSTREL: [singing] He is packing it in and packing it up
And sneaking away and buggering up
And chickening out and pissing off home,
Yes, bravely he is throwing in the sponge.
HEAD KNIGHT: Now he's said the word!
ARTHUR: Surely you've not given up your quest for the Holy Grail?
MINSTREL: [singing] He is sneaking away and buggering up--
HEAD KNIGHT: He said the word again!
ROBIN: I was looking for it.
ROBIN: Uh, here-- here in this forest.
ARTHUR: No, it is far from this place.
NARRATOR: And so, Arthur and Bedevere and Sir Robin set out on their search to find the enchanter of whom the old man had spoken in scene twenty-four.
Beyond the forest, they met Lancelot and Galahad, and there was much rejoicing.
NARRATOR: In the frozen land of Nador, they were forced to eat Robin's minstrels.
NARRATOR: And there was much rejoicing.
NARRATOR: Summer changed back into Winter,...
NARRATOR: ...and Winter gave Spring and Summer a miss and went straight on into Autumn.
SCENE 19: Tim the Enchanter Warns of Rabbit Peril [King Arthur music]
What manner of man are you that can summon up fire without flint or tinder?
ARTHUR: By what name are you known?
TIM: There are some who call me... 'Tim'?
You know much that is hidden, O Tim.
ARTHUR: Yes, we're-- we're looking for the Holy Grail.
Our quest is to find the Holy Grail.
ARTHUR: And so, we're-- we're-- we're looking for it.
BEDEVERE: We have been for some time.
ARTHUR: Uh-- uh, so, uh, anything that you could do to, uh-- to help... would be... very... helpful.
GALAHAD: Look, can you tell us where-- [boom]
Um, I don't want to waste any more of your time, but, uh, I don't suppose you could, uh, tell us where we might find a, um-- find a, uh-- a, um-- a, uh--
ARTHUR: A g-- a-- a g-- a g-- a-- a g--
ARTHUR: Look, um, you're a busy man, uh--
TIM: Yes, I can help you find the Holy Grail.
TIM: To the north there lies a cave-- the cave of Caerbannog-- wherein, carved in mystic runes upon the very living rock, the last words of Olfin Bedwere of Rheged...
ARTHUR: Where could we find this cave, O Tim?
Follow only if ye be men of valour, for the entrance to this cave is guarded by a creature so foul, so cruel that no man yet has fought with it and lived!
Bones of full fifty men lie strewn about its lair.
So, brave knights, if you do doubt your courage or your strength, come no further, for death awaits you all with nasty, big, pointy teeth.
SCENE 20: Faced With a Killer Rabbit - Who's Got the Grenade?
ARTHUR: Then we'd best leave them here and carry on on foot.
TIM: Behold the cave of Caerbannog!
ARTHUR: W-- just keep me covered.
ARTHUR: You got us all worked up!
TIM: Well, that's no ordinary rabbit!
TIM: That's the most foul, cruel, and bad-tempered rodent you ever set eyes on!
TIM: Look, that rabbit's got a vicious streak a mile wide!
TIM: He'll do you up a treat, mate.
ROBIN: What's he do, nibble your bum?
TIM: He's got huge, sharp-- eh-- he can leap about-- look at the bones!
One rabbit stew comin' right up!
TIM: I warned you, but did you listen to me?
Oh, no, you knew it all, didn't you?
Oh, it's just a harmless little bunny, isn't it?
TIM: Do they listen to me?
And we'd better not risk another frontal assault.
ROBIN: Would it help to confuse it if we run away more?
ARTHUR: Oh, shut up and go and change your armor.
It may become so cross that it will make a mistake.
LANCELOT: We have the Holy Hand Grenade.
The Holy Hand Grenade of Antioch!
'Tis one of the sacred relics Brother Maynard carries with him!
Bring up the Holy Hand Grenade!
MONKS: [chanting] Pie Iesu domine, dona eis requiem.
Pie Iesu domine, dona eis requiem.
Pie Iesu domine, dona eis requiem.
Pie Iesu domine, dona eis requiem.
ARTHUR: How does it, um-- how does it work?
LANCELOT: I know not, my liege.
ARTHUR: Consult the Book of Armaments!
BROTHER MAYNARD: Armaments, chapter two, verses nine to twenty-one.
SECOND BROTHER: And Saint Attila raised the hand grenade up on high, saying,
'O Lord, bless this Thy hand grenade that, with it, Thou mayest blow Thine enemies to tiny bits in Thy mercy.'
and the people did feast upon the lambs and sloths and carp and anchovies and orangutans and breakfast cereals and fruit bats and large chu--
SECOND BROTHER: And the Lord spake, saying,
'First shalt thou take out the Holy Pin.
Then, shalt thou count to three.
Three shalt be the number thou shalt count,
and the number of the counting shall be three.
excepting that thou then proceed to three.
Once the number three, being the third number, be reached, then, lobbest thou thy Holy Hand Grenade of Antioch towards thy foe, who, being naughty in My sight, shall snuff it.'
SCENE 21: Don't Go Near the Castle Aarrggh
MAYNARD: It reads, 'Here may be found the last words of Joseph of Arimathea.
He who is valiant and pure of spirit may find the Holy Grail in the Castle of aaarrrrggh'.
MAYNARD: He must have died while carving it.
MAYNARD: Well, that's what it says.
ARTHUR: Look, if he was dying, he wouldn't bother to carve 'aarrggh'.
MAYNARD: Well, that's what's carved in the rock!
Well, does it say anything else?
BEDEVERE: Do you suppose he meant the Camaaaaaargue?
LANCELOT: Isn't there a 'Saint Aaauuves' in Cornwall?
'Aaaauugggh', at the back of the throat, Aaauugh.
BEDEVERE: N-- no. No, no, no, no.
LANCELOT: Oh, you mean sort of a 'aaaah'!
MAYNARD: It's the legendary Black Beast of Aaarrrrggh!
NARRATOR: As the horrendous Black Beast lunged forward, escape for Arthur and his knights seemed hopeless, when suddenly, the animator suffered a fatal heart attack.
NARRATOR: The cartoon peril was no more.
The quest for Holy Grail could continue.
There's the old man from scene twenty-four!
BEDEVERE: What is he doing here?
ARTHUR: He is the keeper of the Bridge of Death.
He asks each traveller five questions--
He who answers the five questions--
ARTHUR: Three questions may cross in safety.
ROBIN: What if you get a question wrong?
ARTHUR: Then you are cast into the Gorge of Eternal Peril.
GALAHAD: Who's going to answer the questions?
ARTHUR: Brave Sir Robin, you go.
LANCELOT: Yes. Let me go, my liege.
I shall make a feint to the north-east that s--
ARTHUR: Three questions as best you can, and we shall watch... and pray.
ARTHUR: Good luck, brave Sir Lancelot.
Who would cross the Bridge of Death must answer me these questions three, ere the other side he see.
LANCELOT: Ask me the questions, bridgekeeper.
LANCELOT: My name is 'Sir Lancelot of Camelot'.
LANCELOT: To seek the Holy Grail.
BRIDGEKEEPER: What... is your favorite color?
Who approacheth the Bridge of Death must answer me these questions three, ere the other side he see.
ROBIN: Ask me the questions, bridgekeeper.
ROBIN: To seek the Holy Grail.

BRIDGEKEEPER: What... is your favorite color?
ARTHUR: It is 'Arthur', King of the Britons.
ARTHUR: To seek the Holy Grail.
BRIDGEKEEPER: What... is the air-speed velocity of an unladen swallow?

ARTHUR: Well, you have to know these things when you're a king, you know.
SCENE 23: The French Fight Dirty or Why Everyone Hates the French
Our quest is at an end!
Almighty God, we thank Thee that Thou hast vouchsafed to us the most holy--
FRENCH GUARD: Allo, dappy English k-niggits and Monsieur Arthur King, who has the brain of a duck, you know.
So, we French fellows outwit you a second time!
ARTHUR: How dare you profane this place with your presence!
I command you, in the name of the Knights of Camelot, to open the doors of this sacred castle, to which God Himself has guided us!
FRENCH GUARD: How you English say, 'I one more time, mac, unclog my nose in your direction', sons of a window-dresser!
So, you think you could out-clever us French folk with your silly knees-bent running about advancing behavior?!
I wave my private parts at your aunties, you cheesy lot of second hand electric donkey-bottom biters.
ARTHUR: In the name of the Lord, we demand entrance to this sacred castle!
FRENCH GUARD: No chance, English bed-wetting types.
I burst my pimples at you and call your door-opening request a silly thing, you tiny-brained wipers of other people's bottoms!
ARTHUR: If you do not open this door, we shall take this castle by force!
In the name of God and the glory of our--
FRENCH GUARD: Yes, depart a lot at this time and cut the approaching any more, or we fire arrows at the tops of your heads and make castanets out of your testicles already!
FRENCH GUARD: And now, remain gone, illegitimate-faced bugger-folk!
And, if you think you got a nasty taunting this time, you ain't heard nothing yet, dappy English k-nnniggits! Thpppt!
ARTHUR: We shall attack at once!
ARTHUR: Today the blood of many a valiant knight shall be avenged.
FRENCH GUARDS: Hoo hoo! Ohh, ha ha ha ha ha!...
ARTHUR: ...we shall not stop our fight till each one of you lies dead and the Holy Grail returns to those whom God has chosen!
HISTORIAN'S WIFE: Yes, they're the ones. I'm sure.
INSPECTOR: Put this man in the van.
My, that's an offensive weapon, that is.
